channel.title: Examples on Measure Theory in Action
channel.description: Recent content in Examples on Measure Theory in Action

item.title: The Set Up
item.description: Defining the Problem $$Q(\lambda)= \frac{1}{M} \sum_{i=1}^M \left(\frac{O_i(\lambda)-d_i}{\sigma_i}\right)^2$$ The distribution of $Q(\lambda)$’s should follow a gamma random variable with shape and rate parameters $M/2$: $$\pi_{\mathcal{D}}(q) = \frac{(M/2)^{M/2}}{\Gamma(M/2)} q^{M/2-1}e^{-Mq/2}$$ Note that the form of $\pi_{\mathcal{D}}(q)$ is independent of the actual time series of data that is observed.
